file.name: BomDom02BomWindow
file.title: Bowser Object Model Window
file.p: The Browser Object Model (BOM) allows JavaScript to interact with the web browser.
file.bullet: The window object is the core of the Browser Object Model. It represents an instance of the web browser.
Through the window object, we can control the browsers:
The window object represents the JavaScript Global object. This means that any variables or functions declared in the global scope become part of the window object.
In an earlier lesson, we covered alert(), confirm(), and prompt(). All of these dialogs are provided by the browser and are made available through the window object.
Since the window object represents the global JavaScript object, the methods can be called directly without mentioning the window object.
Sometimes, it is useful to execute code either at a set interval of time, or after a certain time interval has passed. The window object provides two methods for these purposes.
The setInterval(f, i) method specifies a function to be called at a given time interval.
The setInterval(myFunc(), interval) has two arguments, the function and the interval.
The specified function will continue executing at the given interval until the method clearInterval() is called.
The function can be either a named function or an unnamed function.
MINI LAB Write code to print some alert every 2 seconds. Stop the alerts after 10 seconds.
The setTimeout(f, i) method delays the execution of as function for a specified time interval.
The setTimeout(myFunc(), interval) has two arguments, the function and the interval.
The function can be either a named function or an unnamed function.
The timeout code execution can be cancelled by calling clearTimeout() method.
MINI LAB Write code to print some alert after 3 seconds.
